ANNUAL ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR PUBLIC

2.35 p.m.

    

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates?

Column: 214



    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1961



    

    The Chairman: Main Estimates. For the convenience of Hon. Members, 1 intend taking the total for each head as it appears in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure on page 31 of Paper Cmd. 26 of 1960.

    Dealing now with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper. The amendments are in the Order Paper Supplement No. 3.

Column: 214



    Head 1 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the purpose of this amendment is to seek clarification from the Government as to what it considers the constitutional role of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara to be. Sir, in the constitutional discussions in London, it was urged upon the Colonial Secretary that it would be desirable, in the interests of focusing loyalty on the Queen, to have a Malayan-born Yang di-Pertuan Negara-

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): You mean the contrary.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: And in order that there should be no misunderstanding or misinterpretation that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara goes with the government of the day, it was agreed that the term of office of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara should be four years as against the term of office of the government for five years, so that whatever government succeeds the present Government, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara will be a nominee of the government of the day. But, unfortunately, Sir, some leaders of the P.A.P. in the Party as well as in the Government do seem to give the impression outside and to the Members of the Opposition that the present Yang di-Pertuan Negara is a P.A.P. Yang di-Pertuan Negara. It should not be so. I will just quote an instance where such a misinterpretation could have and has

Column: 215

taken place. I refer to the visit of the Yang di- Pertuan Negara in the early part of this year to the Southern Islands. It is good, it is right, it is proper that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara should visit not only the islands but all parts of Singapore, so as to bring it to the notice of the people of Singapore that we now have a Malayan-born Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Unfortunately, Sir, he was accompanied on his visit to the Southern Islands by a Minister (we can have no objection to that), by Parliamentary Secretaries (to that again we can have no objection), but there were included in that retinue P.A.P. Assemblymen; whereas the elected Member for the Southern Islands was completely ignored. Therefore, we got the impression that here was a P.A.P. Government trying to sell a P.A.P. Yang di-Pertuan Negara. I am sure that that was not the intention. Then there was another instance where this misinterpretation could be given credence. It was because of the advice of certain of the Ministers that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara had, as reported in the papers, given a speech making comparison of Governments-

    

    The Chairman: Order. Will the Member take his seat?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock resumed his seat.

    

    The Chairman: I have been following the hon. Member's speech very closely and I must, of course, be quite satisfied in my mind that he is not offending any of the Standing Orders. One of the Standing Orders is Standing Order 46 (8) which reads:-

    `The conduct of the Sovereign, Members of the Royal Family, or the Yang di-Pertuan Negara shall not be referred to in any circumstances.'.

So that if the hon. Member is now embarking on a dissertation on what the Yang di-Pertuan Negara had said in any of his visits, then I think he is coming very near the line and is probably out of order. But if his speech is levelled solely at the matter he has touched on, that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara is accompanied by P.A.P. Members and P.A.P. Ministers to the exclusion of Opposition Members, then perhaps he is just within the Standing Order. Tun Lim.

Column: 216



    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, what I want to point out in my speech is that Ministers of the Government should understand and realise that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara is our Yang di-Pertuan Negara, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the whole of the people of Singapore. Any advice that any Minister tenders to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara must take into consideration the fact that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara is above politics. If any advice given to him shows a political bent, then it is definitely wrong on the part of the Minister, or the Parliamentary Secretary, or the Government as a whole, to so advise him. It is just like asking the people of Singapore to express loyalty to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, to the flag, to the State anthem. We all will show loyalty to this symbol. But if the wrong impression is given to the people of Singapore that it is a P.A.P. Yang di-Pertuan Negara, a P.A.P. anthem, and a P.A.P. flag, then surely one cannot expect that there would be that loyalty from the people of Singapore.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I am sorry that the leader of the Opposition has seen something to complain about in the conduct of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. I think it is generally accepted that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara is above party politics. He plays an important and impartial constitutional role. I do not wish to go into the circumstances in which it came about that the visit to the Southern Islands was made without the Member for the Southern Islands. It depends upon the circumstances. If it is a visit in connection with a government project, then it may be the opinion of the Minister in charge of that project that the Member of that particular constituency has nothing whatsoever to do with the project as such. The tour of the Southern Islands referred to was in connection with a project to give special development, not just to the Southern Islands but to the Malay community in Kampong Melayu. On that occasion, the Assemblyman for the area was not invited. But it might be of interest to Members of the Opposition to know that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara has expressed the intention to visit as many

Column: 217

of the kampongs on the mainland as possible in the coming year. I do not know if my Secretary has got in touch with the Opposition, but it is proposed that the Yang di-Pertuan Negara makes visits once a fortnight to a particular division and the Assemblyman of that division will introduce him to the community leaders there. I hope that Members of the Opposition will co-operate and make the visit of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara to the kampongs a success. I think the principle goes without challenge, and I am sorry that it should be the subject of any comment in this debate.

2.45 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have made it clear that it is quite all right for Ministers to go to the Southern Islands with the Yang di-Pertuan Negara and the Parliamentary Secretaries, but what I cannot understand is why it was felt necessary that there should be a retinue of P.A.P. Assemblymen; and it is because of the presence of P.A.P. Assemblymen that I raised the point that the elected Member for that particular constituency was not even informed.

    

    The Chairman: Does the Member for Cairnhill wish to take the matter to a vote?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: No. In view of the explanation, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $192,160 for Head 1 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

Column: 217



    Head 2 -

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir,

    I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 2 be reduced by $10 in respect of items (70) to (73) inclusive of sub-head 1.

    The subject concerns the Rent Conciliation Board. Mr Speaker, Sir, after having had some experience in Government, it is my deep feeling that the Rent Conciliation Board in conjunction with the Planning Department and the Land

Column: 218

Office - as a coherent whole - are the instruments of a very privileged landlord class in Singapore to suppress tenants and, in some cases, farmers. Because of that fact, we took steps to reconstitute the Rent Conciliation Board, at the same time re-organising the Planning Department and the Land Office. Earlier, when the Government was being formed, I asked that a certain practising lawyer, who had long been connected with the P.A.P. and who had a long record of service to the underprivileged masses, should become the Chairman of the Rent Conciliation Board. Earlier, when this appointment was discussed.

    The Prime Minister: On a point of order, Sir, I think I had better remind the hon. Member that it is not that there is anything that can be disclosed which would disconcert the Government. It is the principle involved where breaches of the Official Secrets Act and other things would be concerned. I would also like to remind him that what is on the record is on the record; and if he in his peregrinations chooses to refer to fictitious events in order to build up a particular theory, then he does so at great peril. First, it is out of order.

    

    The Chairman: Order. I am just trying to indicate that I would like to hear the point of order before a speech is made.

    The Prime Minister: The point of order, Sir, is this. Is it in order for the ex-Minister for National Development to refer to the processes which led to the appointment which he made of the former Chairman of the Rent Conciliation Board?

    

    The Chairman: Is the point that there is some secrecy in it, Mr Prime Minister?

    The Prime Minister: This was subsequently the subject of some discussion among Ministers in the Cabinet, Sir.

    

    The Chairman: In so far as this Assembly is concerned, I do not think there is anything in the Standing Orders to say that the disclosure of a secret of that nature is against Standing Orders. There is a Standing Order anent

Column: 219

questions on matters secret in nature which cannot be touched upon, but I cannot find anything in the Standing Orders which touches on the point raised. As the Hon. the Prime Minister has rightly pointed out, of course, hon. Members touch on those subjects at their peril, because I do not know whether privilege would apply in cases of that nature. I would not like to give any advice on that.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister was not telling us the truth when he said that the subject matter of the Rent Conciliation Board was discussed in the Cabinet. I must say that it was discussed in the Central Executive Committee of the P.A.P. on 10th January, 1960, and although the members of the Central Executive Committee are also members of the Cabinet, they are held under different conditions, and perhaps in this respect the Prime Minister's mind is confused.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on this issue, the reason why the Prime Minister stood up is that he has played a very dubious role-

    The Prime Minister rose -

    The Chairman: Is it a point of order?

    The Prime Minister: May I just make this point, that if we want to maintain decorum, it should be maintained at all times?

    

    The Chairman: Order. The Prime Minister can rise on a point of order and leave it to the Chair to deal with that point of order. Will the Prime Minister rise on his point of order?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I do not wish to call people names which I am not prepared to substantiate outside. I am prepared to call them names here which I am prepared to call them outside. Perhaps you might consider, Mr Speaker, Sir, for the peace of this House, whether you want to start a little dog fight?

    

    The Chairman: Order. I think hon. Members are forgetting that there are Standing Orders which are rather strict on procedure, that there should not be

Column: 220

a free-for-all in these matters. The point of order is well taken, and I do rule that the word "dubious" is unparliamentary and the Member for Hong Lim should not use that word in relation to a Member of this House.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I hereby withdraw the word "dubious".

    Mr Speaker, Sir, since the Prime Minister is so anxious that his role should not be disclosed, I shall save him from great embarrassment. I shall only deal with the principles of the issue.

    The Prime Minister: Please do.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am only trying to show the fight that is going on in Singapore. Yesterday I spoke of the fight between European capital and local interests, and today I speak of the fight between vested interests in land and the poor tenants.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): You have not forgotten Meadows!

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Woodbridge Hospital!

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Very soon, Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Labour and Law will be sent there after all his powers have been deprived step by step.

    Mr Byrne: He should be certified-

    

    The Chairman: Order. Of course, if the Ministers on the Government Benches intervene with interjections, I suppose one cannot stop a Member from the Opposition Bench from responding. Perhaps if there is some quietude on my right, there may be progress on my left. Mr Ong Eng Guan.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, on 11th December, 1959, in the debate on the Main Estimates of the Budget, the Member for Farrer Park brought up the appointment of the Chairman of the Rent Conciliation Board. He asked this question in Hansard of 11th December, 1959, Volume 11, No. 15 at column 910;

Column: 221

whether the House could be informed that the then Chairman of the Rent Conciliation Board was a practising member of the Bar. At column 912, the Member for Farrer Park went on to say:

    `As far as I understand the Minister's reply, though he did not specifically say so, it would appear, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the present President of the Rent Conciliation Board is, in fact, a practising member of the Bar. If that is accepted, then I will proceed on that basis. I would suggest to the Minister that it is highly undesirable for a practising member of the Bar to be appointed to such a post. In his normal practice, he would come into contact with all sorts of people-tenants, landlords and owners of property. I do not say that he will be influenced by them-but a number of people, who might not otherwise have gone to him on matters other than those appertaining to the Rent Conciliation Board, might go to him and seek his services merely for the reason that when then matters come up before him for consideration as President, they might get an added advantage.'

Mr Speaker, Sir, it was very interesting to see the way the Member for Farrer Park raised this question a year ago. I do not mean to say that this question was inspired by my former colleague the Prime Minister, but I would like to say that not very long after it was raised, this issue was discussed over and over again during the meetings of Assemblymen on Thursday afternoons. At a meeting of the Central Executive Committee of the People's Action Party on 10th January, 1960, the matter was discussed. As a result of that discussion, a decision was reached which was conveyed to all People's Action Party Assemblymen and lawyers. It reads as follows:

    `This is to inform you that the Central

    Executive Committee at its meeting on 10/1/1960 resolved that all statutory boards which have judicial or quasi-judicial functions, for instance, the Rent Conciliation Board, the Income Tax Board of Review, should not include Assemblymen, practising advocates and solicitors, accountants, and persons openly connected with political parties.



    Signed-Ong Pang Boon

    
Organising Secretary

    
24th January, 1960'
Mr Speaker, Sir, as a result of this circular, the then Chairman and eight Assemblymen on the Rent Conciliation

Column: 222

Board resigned. The then Chairman resigned because he was a practising advocate and solicitor. The eight Assemblymen resigned because they were openly connected with political parties.

    Mr Byrne: Obviously.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Labour and Law seems to be inspired after his recent trip to Japan.

    But was this decision carried out in all quasi-judicial and all judicial bodies? It was not. Although the decision mentioned the Income Tax Board of Review, the President of which is Mr Green who happens to be a golfing friend of the Prime Minister [Interruption].

    

    The Chairman: Order. I am going to be very strict about asides of this nature because they are completely irrelevant. They may sometimes be offensive and may lead to disorder in this House. So let us have no asides.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the then Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review was also a practising advocate and solicitor. I believe that not long ago the Chairman, Mr R. H. Green, was replaced - I have a copy here - but he is still a member of the Board of Review. Taking his place is another European practising advocate and solicitor, Mr C. H. Smith. Mr Speaker, it is not possible to ask the Secretary-General of P.A.P. to dismiss the Prime Minister, or, for that matter, the Minister for Finance, for flouting the decisions of the Central of the P.A.P. Mr Speaker. Sir, this is an up-to-date list of the members of the Income Tax Board of Review, showing no less than seven practising lawyers and accountants. So this flouts the decision of the Central of the P.A.P. made on the 10th January, 1960.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not interested in whether members of political parties should or should not openly be members of quasi-judicial organisations. I think there is nothing wrong in that. In the case of practising lawyers, I say there is nothing wrong too, particularly

Column: 223

in the case of the previous Chairman of the Rent Conciliation Board. Before he was appointed to the Board, I extracted a promise from him that he would not take any case concerning the Rent not. But that is not so with the members of the Income Tax Board of Review. The people know that the legal firm of the Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review takes up cases which come up before the Board of Review, although he does not attend those sittings.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another difference is that the members of the Rent Conciliation Board, including the then Chairman, are not paid for their services, but I believe the Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review is paid about $100 or $200 for each sitting, which might last from five minutes to one day.

    Sir, the question of the composition of quasi-judicial organisations, whether the members should or should not be practising lawyers and accountants, or whether the members are openly connected with political parties, is not important. This is a clear and concrete example that the present leaders of the Government, as I proved yesterday, are protecting the interests of vested properties.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, it gives me very little pleasure to expose the stupidities and ignorance of Members of this Assembly, particularly when such an action will hurt innocent parties who were appointed to take over the chairmanship of quasi-judicial tribunals. I am sorry that I have, by implication, to pass this review. About the judicial officers who should have stepped in to prevent the appointment, it is a basic principle, Sir, that justice should not only be done but seem to be done. Whilst I really do not place much weight on the argument put forward by the Member for Farrer Park, that it was because the person concerned is a practising lawyer and therefore should not be the Chairman, I think the sting of the criticism was this: here was a lawyer openly connected with a Party, a Party man, and a member of the Central Executive Committee right up to the time of the elections. He was

Column: 224

provided with eight executioners, all P.A.P. Assemblymen, who were appointed without consultation. They did not know that they were being appointed - the ex-Minister for National Development thought that he would win their support in the Party if he appointed them. Now, Sir, let us get these things straight. Perhaps the ex-Minister for National Development thinks that he is a great champion of the poor, the underprivileged and all the rest of it. What we heard yesterday and this afternoon will doubtless continue.

    The Rent Conciliation Board are concerned with the implementation of the provisions contained in the Control of Rent Ordinance. They can do no exploitation, and they are not in a position to. The exploitation, if any, is contained in the terms of the Ordinance. The provisions of the Ordinance, in so far as they are against the interests of the farmers and in favour of the landlords, have been suspended, and legislation is being prepared and will be introduced in the process of this Budget session to protect their interests permanently. But if you have a quasi-judicial tribunal- first, you are the prosecutor; then you appoint your friend to be the judge, and you provide him with powers to be the assessor; so what is the point of the quasi-judicial tribunal? You could just make an administrative order that that shall be so. In the same way, the Assessment Committee and a few other stupidities which have since been rectified. That is the simple basic principle - that you shall not be judge in your own case and you shall not be prosecutor and judge.

    I am sorry that Mr Tann Wee Tiong was involved. He had a discussion with me and I immediately conceded the difficult position in which he was placed, particularly when he found himself accompanied by eight P.A.P. Assemblymen. They all resigned and Mr Tann Wee Tiong, with good grace, immediately withdrew. Since then a whole panel of people, with the Second Civil District Court Judge as President, have been running the Rent Conciliation Board. They are representatives of the Trades Union Congress and the Chambers of

Column: 225

Commerce, together with three Government pensioners and a retired officer of the City Council. I should hate to imagine, Sir, that representatives of unions, Government pensioners and a City Council retired officer who are serving on a quasi-judicial body - even if it is not at great expense, at least some time and energy and effort is expended on these matters - are instruments of oppression of the poor tenants and farmers at the behest of the landlords. That is not their duty. They are there to allocate rent increases, and control rent of properties where sanitation is put in and roads built, and certain other specified or common improvements are made.

    All I want to point out is this: the stupidity and repetition of lies in which innocent parties are hurt makes this-

    

    The Chairman: Order.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I am not-

    

    The Chairman: Order. I think the word "lies" used in this context obviously refers to what has been said by the Member for Hong Lim. I do not think the Prime Minister is justified in using that unparliamentary word in this Assembly.

    The Prime Minister: I am cheered to know that you, Mr Speaker, Sir, have more regard for his personal reputation than he has himself.

    

    The Chairman: Order. Will the Prime Minister withdraw that word?

    The Prime Minister: I withdraw. I cannot help making that remark, Mr Speaker, Sir. However, may I go on and say this? It is a principle which is extremely important - what we do should be right and appear to be right. We have no intention of running a police State; that is not what we are here for. If you are to implement a principle of the rule of law, then let us at least observe the bare essentials. And for that reason, that directive went out-Party accountants, Party lawyers and Party men should stay out of tribunals where they have to adjudicate on members of the public, and

Column: 226

sometimes the interests of Party men involved. Open identification and open bias is bad. The principle is simple. If that principle is challenged and if the Member for Hong Lim believes that that principle is being enforced because we want an instrument to oppress the people, then I think he is well on the way to one of the reputable institutions that were referred to in the asides.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): The Member for Hong Lim. Mr Speaker, referred to the membership of the Income Tax Board and I would like to make some points of clarification. Yesterday I had occasion to draw attention to certain regrettable perplexities of the Member for Hong Lim, and I pointed out several serious mis-statements of fact which he made in his speech. Today, within practically the first hour of this sitting of the Assembly, he perpetrated another. The Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review is a District Judge appointed in accordance with the policy enunciated by this Government.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I just want to correct the suggestion by the ex-Minister for National Development that there has been manipulation by the Prime Minister in this matter.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I was aware of the directive of the Central Executive Committee of the Party. I was present at the meeting and it was my duty to carry out the recommendation of the Central Executive Committee. If the Member for Hong Lim will just look at page 42 of these Estimates, "Remarks" column-against the post "First Civil District Judge", he will see that the salary scale of that post was revised by Establishment Warrant No. 26/60 from the timescale salary $1,100-40A-1,420 to a Grade F post, drawing a salary of $1,620. It was my duty to take this matter up with the Minister for Finance in view of the Central Executive Committee's decision that there should be no practising member of the Bar as Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review. It was the intention, Mr Speaker,

Column: 227

Sir, that the person who was to fill this post of Civil District Judge should also be the Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review. And we have on our side faithfully implemented the decision of the Central Executive Committee, so that there has been no manipulation whatsoever on the part of the Prime Minister. I was present at the Central Executive Committee meeting when that decision was made, and it was my duty to see that it was implemented. I therefore took it up with the Minister for Finance. As a result of that, there has been this revision of the salary of the post of "Civil District Judge". I cannot see how such a suggestion can honestly be made by a former member of the Central Executive Committee and a responsible person who is a Member of the Legislative Assembly for the constituency of Hong Lim. I am indeed surprised that that suggestion should have come from him today.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very grateful for the impartial interpretation of the decision of the Central made just now by the Minister for Labour and Law. The decision was that it was wrong for a practising advocate and solicitor to be chairman of any quasi-judicial organisation and not, as the Prime Minister has said just now, that it was not wrong for a practising lawyer to be chairman but that it was wrong for a political practising lawyer to be chairman. They are two different interpretations altogether. So, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very grateful for the assurance given us by the Minister for Labour and Law, that there is a Budget provision that a First Civil District Judge has been appointed. According to the Minister for Finance, Mr Jeyaratnam has been appointed to be Chairman of the Income Tax Board of Review. But, Mr Speaker, I have had a letter from the Ministry of Finance only two days back saying that the Chairman is Mr C. H. Smith. I wonder whether the Minister for Finance has control of Mr H. G. Wells' "The Time Machine",

Column: 228

so that he can go forward and backward any time he likes. If the Minister wants to have a look at this letter, I shall pass it over to him. Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion, that issue is not important. The issue is this: that the leaders of the Government are now, in full force, with all honesty and sincerity, protecting vested interests.
